--- title: "2.1 — David Hume and Adam Smith the Philosopher — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"} # Meeting Dates *Tuesday, September 20, 2022* ::: ## Overview Today we discuss Hume and begin Smith. ## Readings ### Required Readings: - David Hume, *Political Discourses*, and Adam Smith (but not *WON* yet) in *Reader* ### If You Hadn't Yet: - Start Ch.4 "Adam Smith" in Landreth & Colander - Start Ch.2 "Adam Smith" in Blaug ### Recommended Readings: The following Wikipedia entries can also provide more background on these writers and their famous works: - [ *Econtalk*: Dennis Rasmussen on Hume and Smith and The Infidel and the Professor](https://www.econtalk.org/dennis-rasmussen-on-hume-and-smith-and-the-infidel-and-the-professor/) - [ *Econtalk*: Russ Roberts and Mike Munger on How Adam Smith Can Change Your Life](https://www.econtalk.org/dennis-rasmussen-on-hume-and-smith-and-the-infidel-and-the-professor/) - [ Roberts, *How Adam Smith Can Change Your Life: An Unexpected Guide to Human Nature and Happiness*](https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1591847958) - [ David Hume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Hume) - [ Adam Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam_Smith) - [ Theory of Moral Sentiments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Theory_of_Moral_Sentiments) ### Questions to Help Your Reading - Is David Hume a mercantilist, a Classical economist, or some mix? (Your textbooks seem to disagree!) - What do Hume and Smith mean by "sentiments?" - How does Hume approach money? In what ways is his quantity theory of money similar to, and different from, John Locke's? - What is Hume's "price-specie flow mechanism"? How does this connect with a gold standard (or similar commodity-based money)? - How does Hume criticize mercantilism? - According to Hume, where does interest come from, and how are interest rates determined? Is it based on the money supply, as some mercantilists supposed? ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab. The lower button will allow you to download a PDF version of the slides. ::: callout-tip You can type h to see a special list of viewing options, and type o for an outline view of all the slides. ::: I suggest printing the slides beforehand and using them to take additional notes in class (*not everything* is in the slides)!
